God give me joy to wear it, for my heart is
exceeding heavy.

sp.speaker: MARGARET
sp.p:
’Twill be heavier soon by the weight of a
man.

sp.speaker: HERO
sp.p: Fie upon thee! Art not ashamed?

sp.speaker: MARGARET
sp.p:
Of what, lady? Of speaking honorably? Is
not marriage honorable in a beggar? Is not your
lord honorable without marriage? I think you
would have me say “ Saving your reverence, a husband.”
An bad thinking do not wrest true speaking,
I’ll offend nobody. Is there any harm in “ the heavier
for a husband”? None, I think, an it be the right
husband and the right wife. Otherwise, ’tis light and
not heavy. Ask my lady Beatrice else. Here she
comes.

sp.speaker: HERO
sp.p: Good morrow, coz.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p: Good morrow, sweet Hero.

sp.speaker: HERO
sp.p: Why, how now? Do you speak in the sick tune?

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p: I am out of all other tune, methinks.

sp.speaker: MARGARET
sp.p:
Clap ’s into “ Light o’ love.” That goes
without a burden. Do you sing it, and I’ll dance it.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
You light o’ love with your heels! Then, if
your husband have stables enough, you’ll see he
shall lack no barns.

sp.speaker: MARGARET
sp.p:
O, illegitimate construction! I scorn that
with my heels.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
’Tis almost five o’clock, cousin. ’Tis time
you were ready. By my troth, I am exceeding ill.
Heigh-ho!

sp.speaker: MARGARET
sp.p: For a hawk, a horse, or a husband?

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p: For the letter that begins them all, H.

sp.speaker: MARGARET
sp.p:
Well, an you be not turned Turk, there’s no
more sailing by the star.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p: What means the fool, trow?

sp.speaker: MARGARET
sp.p:
Nothing, I; but God send everyone their
heart’s desire.

sp.speaker: HERO
sp.p:
These gloves the Count sent me, they are an
excellent perfume.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p: I am stuffed, cousin. I cannot smell.

sp.speaker: MARGARET
sp.p:
A maid, and stuffed! There’s goodly catching
of cold.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
O, God help me, God help me! How long
have you professed apprehension?

sp.speaker: MARGARET
sp.p:
Ever since you left it. Doth not my wit
become me rarely?

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
It is not seen enough; you should wear it in
your cap. By my troth, I am sick.

sp.speaker: MARGARET
sp.p:
Get you some of this distilled carduus benedictus
and lay it to your heart. It is the only thing for
a qualm.

sp.speaker: HERO
sp.p: There thou prick’st her with a thistle.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
Benedictus! Why benedictus? You have some
moral in this benedictus?

sp.speaker: MARGARET
sp.p:
Moral? No, by my troth, I have no moral
meaning; I meant plain holy thistle. You may think
perchance that I think you are in love. Nay, by ’r
Lady, I am not such a fool to think what I list, nor I
list not to think what I can, nor indeed I cannot
think, if I would think my heart out of thinking, that
you are in love or that you will be in love or that you
can be in love. Yet Benedick was such another, and
now is he become a man. He swore he would never
marry, and yet now, in despite of his heart, he eats
his meat without grudging. And how you may be
converted I know not, but methinks you look with
your eyes as other women do.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p: What pace is this that thy tongue keeps?

sp.speaker: MARGARET
sp.p: Not a false gallop.

sp.speaker: URSULA
sp.p:
Madam, withdraw. The Prince, the Count,
Signior Benedick, Don John, and all the gallants of
the town are come to fetch you to church.

sp.speaker: HERO
sp.p:
Help to dress me, good coz, good Meg, good
Ursula.

div.head: Scene 5
div.stage: Enter Leonato, and Dogberry, the Constable, and Verges, the Headborough.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p: What would you with me, honest neighbor?

sp.speaker: DOGBERRY
sp.p:
Marry, sir, I would have some confidence
with you that decerns you nearly.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p:
Brief, I pray you, for you see it is a busy time
with me.

sp.speaker: DOGBERRY
sp.p: Marry, this it is, sir.

sp.speaker: VERGES
sp.p: Yes, in truth, it is, sir.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p: What is it, my good friends?

sp.speaker: DOGBERRY
sp.p:
Goodman Verges, sir, speaks a little off the
matter. An old man, sir, and his wits are not so blunt
as, God help, I would desire they were, but, in faith,
honest as the skin between his brows.

sp.speaker: VERGES
sp.p:
Yes, I thank God I am as honest as any man
living that is an old man and no honester than I.

sp.speaker: DOGBERRY
sp.p:
Comparisons are odorous. Palabras, neighbor
Verges.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p: Neighbors, you are tedious.

sp.speaker: DOGBERRY
sp.p:
It pleases your Worship to say so, but we
are the poor duke’s officers. But truly, for mine
own part, if I were as tedious as a king, I could find
in my heart to bestow it all of your Worship.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p: All thy tediousness on me, ah?

sp.speaker: DOGBERRY
sp.p:
Yea, an ’twere a thousand pound more
than ’tis, for I hear as good exclamation on your
Worship as of any man in the city, and though I be
but a poor man, I am glad to hear it.

sp.speaker: VERGES
sp.p: And so am I.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p: I would fain know what you have to say.

sp.speaker: VERGES
sp.p:
Marry, sir, our watch tonight, excepting your
Worship’s presence, ha’ ta’en a couple of as arrant
knaves as any in Messina.

sp.speaker: DOGBERRY
sp.p:
A good old man, sir. He will be talking. As
they say, “ When the age is in, the wit is out.” God
help us, it is a world to see!— Well said, i’ faith,
neighbor Verges.— Well, God’s a good man. An two
men ride of a horse, one must ride behind. An
honest soul, i’ faith, sir, by my troth he is, as ever
broke bread, but God is to be worshiped, all men
are not alike, alas, good neighbor.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p: Indeed, neighbor, he comes too short of you.

sp.speaker: DOGBERRY
sp.p: Gifts that God gives.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p: I must leave you.

sp.speaker: DOGBERRY
sp.p:
One word, sir. Our watch, sir, have indeed
comprehended two aspicious persons, and we
would have them this morning examined before
your Worship.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p:
Take their examination yourself and bring it
me. I am now in great haste, as it may appear unto
you.

sp.speaker: DOGBERRY
sp.p: It shall be suffigance.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p: Drink some wine ere you go. Fare you well.

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.p:
My lord, they stay for you to give your
daughter to her husband.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p: I’ll wait upon them. I am ready.

sp.speaker: DOGBERRY
sp.p:
Go, good partner, go, get you to Francis
Seacoal. Bid him bring his pen and inkhorn to the
jail. We are now to examination these men.

sp.speaker: VERGES
sp.p: And we must do it wisely.

sp.speaker: DOGBERRY
sp.p:
We will spare for no wit, I warrant you.
Here’s that shall drive some of them to a noncome.
Only get the learned writer to set down our excommunication
and meet me at the jail.

div.head: Scene 1
div.stage: Enter Prince, John the Bastard, Leonato, Friar, Claudio, Benedick, Hero, and Beatrice, with Attendants.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p:
Come, Friar Francis, be brief, only to the
plain form of marriage, and you shall recount their
particular duties afterwards.

sp.speaker: FRIAR
sp.p:
You come hither, my lord, to marry
this lady?

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p:
To be married to her.— Friar, you come to
marry her.

sp.speaker: FRIAR
sp.p:
Lady, you come hither to be married to this
count?

sp.speaker: HERO
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: FRIAR
sp.p:
If either of you know any inward impediment
why you should not be conjoined, I charge you on
your souls to utter it.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p: Know you any, Hero?

sp.speaker: HERO
sp.p: None, my lord.

sp.speaker: FRIAR
sp.p: Know you any, count?

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p: I dare make his answer, none.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p:
O, what men dare do! What men may do!
What men daily do, not knowing what they do!

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
How now, interjections? Why, then, some
be of laughing, as ah, ha, he!

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.l: Stand thee by, friar.— Father, by your leave,
Will you with free and unconstrainèd soul
Give me this maid, your daughter?

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.l: As freely, son, as God did give her me.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.l: And what have I to give you back whose worth
May counterpoise this rich and precious gift?

sp.speaker: PRINCE
sp.l: Nothing, unless you render her again.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.l: Sweet prince, you learn me noble thankfulness.—
There, Leonato, take her back again.
Give not this rotten orange to your friend.
She’s but the sign and semblance of her honor.
Behold how like a maid she blushes here!
O, what authority and show of truth
Can cunning sin cover itself withal!
Comes not that blood as modest evidence
To witness simple virtue? Would you not swear,
All you that see her, that she were a maid,
By these exterior shows? But she is none.
She knows the heat of a luxurious bed.
Her blush is guiltiness, not modesty.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.l: What do you mean, my lord?

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.l: Not to be married,
Not to knit my soul to an approvèd wanton.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.l: Dear my lord, if you in your own proof
Have vanquished the resistance of her youth,
And made defeat of her virginity—

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.l: I know what you would say: if I have known her,
You will say she did embrace me as a husband,
And so extenuate the forehand sin.
No, Leonato,
I never tempted her with word too large,
But, as a brother to his sister, showed
Bashful sincerity and comely love.

sp.speaker: HERO
sp.l: And seemed I ever otherwise to you?

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.l: Out on thee, seeming! I will write against it.
You seem to me as Dian in her orb,
As chaste as is the bud ere it be blown.
But you are more intemperate in your blood
Than Venus, or those pampered animals
That rage in savage sensuality.

sp.speaker: HERO
sp.l: Is my lord well that he doth speak so wide?

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.l: Sweet prince, why speak not you?

sp.speaker: PRINCE
sp.l: What should I speak?
I stand dishonored that have gone about
To link my dear friend to a common stale.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.l: Are these things spoken, or do I but dream?

sp.speaker: DON JOHN
sp.l: Sir, they are spoken, and these things are true.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.l: This looks not like a nuptial.

sp.speaker: HERO
sp.l: True! O God!

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.l: Leonato, stand I here?
Is this the Prince? Is this the Prince’s brother?
Is this face Hero’s? Are our eyes our own?

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.l: All this is so, but what of this, my lord?

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.l: Let me but move one question to your daughter,
And by that fatherly and kindly power
That you have in her, bid her answer truly.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.l: I charge thee do so, as thou art my child.

sp.speaker: HERO
sp.l: O, God defend me, how am I beset!—
What kind of catechizing call you this?

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.l: To make you answer truly to your name.

sp.speaker: HERO
sp.l: Is it not Hero? Who can blot that name
With any just reproach?

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.l: Marry, that can Hero!
Hero itself can blot out Hero’s virtue.
What man was he talked with you yesternight
Out at your window betwixt twelve and one?
Now, if you are a maid, answer to this.

sp.speaker: HERO
sp.l: I talked with no man at that hour, my lord.

sp.speaker: PRINCE
sp.l: Why, then, are you no maiden.— Leonato,
I am sorry you must hear. Upon mine honor,
Myself, my brother, and this grievèd count
Did see her, hear her, at that hour last night
Talk with a ruffian at her chamber window,
Who hath indeed, most like a liberal villain,
Confessed the vile encounters they have had
A thousand times in secret.

sp.speaker: DON JOHN
sp.l: Fie, fie, they are not to be named, my lord,
Not to be spoke of!
There is not chastity enough in language,
Without offense, to utter them.— Thus, pretty lady,
I am sorry for thy much misgovernment.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.l: O Hero, what a Hero hadst thou been
If half thy outward graces had been placed
About thy thoughts and counsels of thy heart!
But fare thee well, most foul, most fair. Farewell,
Thou pure impiety and impious purity.
For thee I’ll lock up all the gates of love
And on my eyelids shall conjecture hang,
To turn all beauty into thoughts of harm,
And never shall it more be gracious.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.l: Hath no man’s dagger here a point for me?

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.l: Why, how now, cousin, wherefore sink you down?

sp.speaker: DON JOHN
sp.l: Come, let us go. These things, come thus to light,
Smother her spirits up.

div.stage: Claudio, Prince, and Don John exit.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.l: How doth the lady?

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.l: Dead, I think.— Help, uncle!—
Hero, why Hero! Uncle! Signior Benedick! Friar!

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.l: O Fate, take not away thy heavy hand!
Death is the fairest cover for her shame
That may be wished for.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.l: How now, cousin Hero?

sp.speaker: FRIAR
sp.l: Have comfort, lady.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.l: Dost thou look up?

sp.speaker: FRIAR
sp.l: Yea, wherefore should she not?

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.l: Wherefore? Why, doth not every earthly thing
Cry shame upon her? Could she here deny
The story that is printed in her blood?—
Do not live, Hero, do not ope thine eyes,
For, did I think thou wouldst not quickly die,
Thought I thy spirits were stronger than thy shames,
Myself would, on the rearward of reproaches,
Strike at thy life. Grieved I I had but one?
Chid I for that at frugal Nature’s frame?
O, one too much by thee! Why had I one?
Why ever wast thou lovely in my eyes?
Why had I not with charitable hand
Took up a beggar’s issue at my gates,
Who, smirchèd thus, and mired with infamy,
I might have said “ No part of it is mine;
This shame derives itself from unknown loins”?
But mine, and mine I loved, and mine I praised,
And mine that I was proud on, mine so much
That I myself was to myself not mine,
Valuing of her— why she, O she, is fall’n
Into a pit of ink, that the wide sea
Hath drops too few to wash her clean again,
And salt too little which may season give
To her foul tainted flesh!

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.l: Sir, sir, be patient.
For my part, I am so attired in wonder
I know not what to say.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.l: O, on my soul, my cousin is belied!

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.l: Lady, were you her bedfellow last night?

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.l: No, truly not, although until last night
I have this twelvemonth been her bedfellow.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.l: Confirmed, confirmed! O, that is stronger made
Which was before barred up with ribs of iron!
Would the two princes lie and Claudio lie,
Who loved her so that, speaking of her foulness,
Washed it with tears? Hence from her. Let her die!

sp.speaker: FRIAR
sp.l: Hear me a little,
For I have only silent been so long,
And given way unto this course of fortune,
By noting of the lady. I have marked
A thousand blushing apparitions
To start into her face, a thousand innocent shames
In angel whiteness beat away those blushes,
And in her eye there hath appeared a fire
To burn the errors that these princes hold
Against her maiden truth. Call me a fool,
Trust not my reading nor my observations,
Which with experimental seal doth warrant
The tenor of my book; trust not my age,
My reverence, calling, nor divinity,
If this sweet lady lie not guiltless here
Under some biting error.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.l: Friar, it cannot be.
Thou seest that all the grace that she hath left
Is that she will not add to her damnation
A sin of perjury. She not denies it.
Why seek’st thou then to cover with excuse
That which appears in proper nakedness?

sp.speaker: FRIAR
sp.l: Lady, what man is he you are accused of?

sp.speaker: HERO
sp.l: They know that do accuse me. I know none.
If I know more of any man alive
Than that which maiden modesty doth warrant,
Let all my sins lack mercy!— O my father,
Prove you that any man with me conversed
At hours unmeet, or that I yesternight
Maintained the change of words with any creature,
Refuse me, hate me, torture me to death!

sp.speaker: FRIAR
sp.l: There is some strange misprision in the princes.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.l: Two of them have the very bent of honor,
And if their wisdoms be misled in this,
The practice of it lives in John the Bastard,
Whose spirits toil in frame of villainies.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.l: I know not. If they speak but truth of her,
These hands shall tear her. If they wrong her honor,
The proudest of them shall well hear of it.
Time hath not yet so dried this blood of mine,
Nor age so eat up my invention,
Nor fortune made such havoc of my means,
Nor my bad life reft me so much of friends,
But they shall find, awaked in such a kind,
Both strength of limb and policy of mind,
Ability in means and choice of friends,
To quit me of them throughly.

sp.speaker: FRIAR
sp.l: Pause awhile,
And let my counsel sway you in this case.
Your daughter here the princes left for dead.
Let her awhile be secretly kept in,
And publish it that she is dead indeed.
Maintain a mourning ostentation,
And on your family’s old monument
Hang mournful epitaphs and do all rites
That appertain unto a burial.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.l: What shall become of this? What will this do?

sp.speaker: FRIAR
sp.l: Marry, this well carried shall on her behalf
Change slander to remorse. That is some good.
But not for that dream I on this strange course,
But on this travail look for greater birth.
She, dying, as it must be so maintained,
Upon the instant that she was accused,
Shall be lamented, pitied, and excused
Of every hearer. For it so falls out
That what we have we prize not to the worth
Whiles we enjoy it, but being lacked and lost,
Why then we rack the value, then we find
The virtue that possession would not show us
Whiles it was ours. So will it fare with Claudio.
When he shall hear she died upon his words,
Th’ idea of her life shall sweetly creep
Into his study of imagination,
And every lovely organ of her life
Shall come appareled in more precious habit,
More moving, delicate, and full of life,
Into the eye and prospect of his soul,
Than when she lived indeed. Then shall he mourn,
If ever love had interest in his liver,
And wish he had not so accused her,
No, though he thought his accusation true.
Let this be so, and doubt not but success
Will fashion the event in better shape
Than I can lay it down in likelihood.
But if all aim but this be leveled false,
The supposition of the lady’s death
Will quench the wonder of her infamy.
And if it sort not well, you may conceal her,
As best befits her wounded reputation,
In some reclusive and religious life,
Out of all eyes, tongues, minds, and injuries.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.l: Signior Leonato, let the Friar advise you.
And though you know my inwardness and love
Is very much unto the Prince and Claudio,
Yet, by mine honor, I will deal in this
As secretly and justly as your soul
Should with your body.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.l: Being that I flow in grief,
The smallest twine may lead me.

lg.l: ’Tis well consented. Presently away,
For to strange sores strangely they strain the cure.—
Come, lady, die to live. This wedding day
Perhaps is but prolonged. Have patience and endure.
lg.stage: All but Beatrice and Benedick exit.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p: Lady Beatrice, have you wept all this while?

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p: Yea, and I will weep a while longer.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p: I will not desire that.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p: You have no reason. I do it freely.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
Surely I do believe your fair cousin is
wronged.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
Ah, how much might the man deserve of me
that would right her!

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p: Is there any way to show such friendship?

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p: A very even way, but no such friend.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p: May a man do it?

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p: It is a man’s office, but not yours.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
I do love nothing in the world so well as
you. Is not that strange?

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
As strange as the thing I know not. It were as
possible for me to say I loved nothing so well as you,
but believe me not, and yet I lie not; I confess
nothing, nor I deny nothing. I am sorry for my
cousin.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p: By my sword, Beatrice, thou lovest me!

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p: Do not swear and eat it.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
I will swear by it that you love me, and I will
make him eat it that says I love not you.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p: Will you not eat your word?

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
With no sauce that can be devised to it. I
protest I love thee.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p: Why then, God forgive me.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p: What offense, sweet Beatrice?

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
You have stayed me in a happy hour. I was
about to protest I loved you.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p: And do it with all thy heart.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
I love you with so much of my heart that
none is left to protest.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p: Come, bid me do anything for thee.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p: Kill Claudio.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p: Ha! Not for the wide world.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p: You kill me to deny it. Farewell.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p: Tarry, sweet Beatrice.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
I am gone, though I am here. There is no
love in you. Nay, I pray you let me go.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p: Beatrice—

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p: In faith, I will go.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p: We’ll be friends first.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
You dare easier be friends with me than
fight with mine enemy.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p: Is Claudio thine enemy?

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
Is he not approved in the height a villain
that hath slandered, scorned, dishonored my kinswoman?
O, that I were a man! What, bear her in
hand until they come to take hands, and then, with
public accusation, uncovered slander, unmitigated
rancor— O God, that I were a man! I would eat his
heart in the marketplace.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p: Hear me, Beatrice—

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
Talk with a man out at a window! A proper
saying.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p: Nay, but Beatrice—

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
Sweet Hero, she is wronged, she is slandered,
she is undone.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p: Beat—

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
Princes and counties! Surely a princely testimony,
a goodly count, Count Comfect, a sweet
gallant, surely! O, that I were a man for his sake! Or
that I had any friend would be a man for my sake!
But manhood is melted into curtsies, valor into
compliment, and men are only turned into tongue,
and trim ones, too. He is now as valiant as Hercules
that only tells a lie and swears it. I cannot be a man
with wishing; therefore I will die a woman with
grieving.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
Tarry, good Beatrice. By this hand, I love
thee.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
Use it for my love some other way than
swearing by it.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
Think you in your soul the Count Claudio
hath wronged Hero?

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p: Yea, as sure as I have a thought or a soul.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
Enough, I am engaged. I will challenge
him. I will kiss your hand, and so I leave you. By
this hand, Claudio shall render me a dear account.
As you hear of me, so think of me. Go comfort your
cousin. I must say she is dead, and so farewell.

div.head: Scene 2
div.stage: Enter the Constables Dogberry and Verges, and the Town Clerk, or Sexton, in gowns, with the Watch, Conrade, and Borachio.

sp.speaker: DOGBERRY
sp.p: Is our whole dissembly appeared?

sp.speaker: VERGES
sp.p: O, a stool and a cushion for the Sexton.

div.stage: A stool is brought in; the Sexton sits.

sp.speaker: SEXTON
sp.p: Which be the malefactors?

sp.speaker: DOGBERRY
sp.p: Marry, that am I, and my partner.

sp.speaker: VERGES
sp.p:
Nay, that’s certain, we have the exhibition to
examine.

sp.speaker: SEXTON
sp.p:
But which are the offenders that are to be
examined? Let them come before Master
Constable.

sp.speaker: DOGBERRY
sp.p: Yea, marry, let them come before me.
sp.stage: Conrade and Borachio are brought forward.
sp.p: What is your name, friend?

sp.speaker: BORACHIO
sp.p: Borachio.

sp.speaker: DOGBERRY
sp.p:
Pray, write down “ Borachio.”— Yours,
sirrah?

sp.speaker: CONRADE
sp.p:
I am a gentleman, sir, and my name is
Conrade.

sp.speaker: DOGBERRY
sp.p:
Write down “ Master Gentleman Conrade.”—
Masters, do you serve God?

sp.speaker: BORACHIO/ CONRADE
sp.p: Yea, sir, we hope.

sp.speaker: DOGBERRY
sp.p:
Write down that they hope they serve
God; and write God first, for God defend but God
should go before such villains!— Masters, it is
proved already that you are little better than false
knaves, and it will go near to be thought so shortly.
How answer you for yourselves?

sp.speaker: CONRADE
sp.p: Marry, sir, we say we are none.

sp.speaker: DOGBERRY
sp.p:
A marvelous witty fellow, I assure you,
but I will go about with him.— Come you hither,
sirrah, a word in your ear. Sir, I say to you it is
thought you are false knaves.

sp.speaker: BORACHIO
sp.p: Sir, I say to you we are none.

sp.speaker: DOGBERRY
sp.p:
Well, stand aside.— ’Fore God, they are
both in a tale. Have you writ down that they are
none?

sp.speaker: SEXTON
sp.p:
Master constable, you go not the way to
examine. You must call forth the watch that are
their accusers.

sp.speaker: DOGBERRY
sp.p:
Yea, marry, that’s the eftest way.— Let
the watch come forth. Masters, I charge you in the
Prince’s name, accuse these men.

sp.speaker: FIRST WATCHMAN
sp.p:
This man said, sir, that Don John, the
Prince’s brother, was a villain.

sp.speaker: DOGBERRY
sp.p:
Write down Prince John a villain. Why,
this is flat perjury, to call a prince’s brother villain!

sp.speaker: BORACHIO
sp.p: Master constable—

sp.speaker: DOGBERRY
sp.p:
Pray thee, fellow, peace. I do not like thy
look, I promise thee.

sp.speaker: SEXTON
sp.p: What heard you him say else?

sp.speaker: SEACOAL
sp.p:
Marry, that he had received a thousand
ducats of Don John for accusing the Lady Hero
wrongfully.

sp.speaker: DOGBERRY
sp.p: Flat burglary as ever was committed.

sp.speaker: VERGES
sp.p: Yea, by Mass, that it is.

sp.speaker: SEXTON
sp.p: What else, fellow?

sp.speaker: FIRST WATCHMAN
sp.p:
And that Count Claudio did mean,
upon his words, to disgrace Hero before the whole
assembly, and not marry her.

sp.speaker: DOGBERRY
sp.p:
O, villain! Thou wilt be condemned
into everlasting redemption for this!

sp.speaker: SEXTON
sp.p: What else?

sp.speaker: SEACOAL
sp.p: This is all.

sp.speaker: SEXTON
sp.p:
And this is more, masters, than you can deny.
Prince John is this morning secretly stolen away.
Hero was in this manner accused, in this very
manner refused, and upon the grief of this suddenly
died.— Master constable, let these men be bound
and brought to Leonato’s. I will go before and show
him their examination.

sp.speaker: DOGBERRY
sp.p: Come, let them be opinioned.

sp.speaker: VERGES
sp.p: Let them be in the hands—

sp.speaker: CONRADE
sp.p: Off, coxcomb!

sp.speaker: DOGBERRY
sp.p:
God’s my life, where’s the Sexton? Let
him write down the Prince’s officer “ coxcomb.”
Come, bind them.— Thou naughty varlet!

sp.speaker: CONRADE
sp.p: Away! You are an ass, you are an ass!

sp.speaker: DOGBERRY
sp.p:
Dost thou not suspect my place? Dost
thou not suspect my years? O, that he were here to
write me down an ass! But masters, remember that
I am an ass, though it be not written down, yet
forget not that I am an ass.— No, thou villain, thou
art full of piety, as shall be proved upon thee by
good witness. I am a wise fellow and, which is more,
an officer and, which is more, a householder and,
which is more, as pretty a piece of flesh as any is in
Messina, and one that knows the law, go to, and a
rich fellow enough, go to, and a fellow that hath had
losses, and one that hath two gowns and everything
handsome about him.— Bring him away.— O, that I
had been writ down an ass!

div.head: Scene 1

sp.speaker: LEONATO’S BROTHER
sp.l: If you go on thus, you will kill yourself,
And ’tis not wisdom thus to second grief
Against yourself.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.l: I pray thee, cease thy counsel,
Which falls into mine ears as profitless
As water in a sieve. Give not me counsel,
Nor let no comforter delight mine ear
But such a one whose wrongs do suit with mine.
Bring me a father that so loved his child,
Whose joy of her is overwhelmed like mine,
And bid him speak of patience.
Measure his woe the length and breadth of mine,
And let it answer every strain for strain,
As thus for thus, and such a grief for such,
In every lineament, branch, shape, and form.
If such a one will smile and stroke his beard,
Bid sorrow wag, cry “ hem” when he should groan,
Patch grief with proverbs, make misfortune drunk
With candle-wasters, bring him yet to me,
And I of him will gather patience.
But there is no such man. For, brother, men
Can counsel and speak comfort to that grief
Which they themselves not feel, but tasting it,
Their counsel turns to passion, which before
Would give preceptial med’cine to rage,
Fetter strong madness in a silken thread,
Charm ache with air and agony with words.
No, no, ’tis all men’s office to speak patience
To those that wring under the load of sorrow,
But no man’s virtue nor sufficiency
To be so moral when he shall endure
The like himself. Therefore give me no counsel.
My griefs cry louder than advertisement.

sp.speaker: LEONATO’S BROTHER
sp.l: Therein do men from children nothing differ.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.l: I pray thee, peace. I will be flesh and blood,
For there was never yet philosopher
That could endure the toothache patiently,
However they have writ the style of gods
And made a push at chance and sufferance.

sp.speaker: LEONATO’S BROTHER
sp.l: Yet bend not all the harm upon yourself.
Make those that do offend you suffer too.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.l: There thou speak’st reason. Nay, I will do so.
My soul doth tell me Hero is belied,
And that shall Claudio know; so shall the Prince
And all of them that thus dishonor her.

sp.speaker: LEONATO’S BROTHER
sp.l: Here comes the Prince and Claudio hastily.

sp.speaker: PRINCE
sp.l: Good e’en, good e’en.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.l: Good day to both of you.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.l: Hear you, my lords—

sp.speaker: PRINCE
sp.l: We have some haste, Leonato.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.l: Some haste, my lord! Well, fare you well, my lord.
Are you so hasty now? Well, all is one.

sp.speaker: PRINCE
sp.l: Nay, do not quarrel with us, good old man.

sp.speaker: LEONATO’S BROTHER
sp.l: If he could right himself with quarrelling,
Some of us would lie low.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.l: Who wrongs him?

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.l: Marry, thou dost wrong me, thou dissembler, thou.
Nay, never lay thy hand upon thy sword.
I fear thee not.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.l: Marry, beshrew my hand
If it should give your age such cause of fear.
In faith, my hand meant nothing to my sword.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.l: Tush, tush, man, never fleer and jest at me.
I speak not like a dotard nor a fool,
As under privilege of age to brag
What I have done being young, or what would do
Were I not old. Know, Claudio, to thy head,
Thou hast so wronged mine innocent child and me
That I am forced to lay my reverence by,
And with gray hairs and bruise of many days
Do challenge thee to trial of a man.
I say thou hast belied mine innocent child.
Thy slander hath gone through and through her heart,
And she lies buried with her ancestors,
O, in a tomb where never scandal slept,
Save this of hers, framed by thy villainy.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.l: My villainy?

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.l: Thine, Claudio, thine, I say.

sp.speaker: PRINCE
sp.l: You say not right, old man.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.l: My lord, my lord,
I’ll prove it on his body if he dare,
Despite his nice fence and his active practice,
His May of youth and bloom of lustihood.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.l: Away! I will not have to do with you.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.l: Canst thou so daff me? Thou hast killed my child.
If thou kill’st me, boy, thou shalt kill a man.

sp.speaker: LEONATO’S BROTHER
sp.l: He shall kill two of us, and men indeed,
But that’s no matter. Let him kill one first.
Win me and wear me! Let him answer me.—
Come, follow me, boy. Come, sir boy, come, follow me.
Sir boy, I’ll whip you from your foining fence,
Nay, as I am a gentleman, I will.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.l: Brother—

sp.speaker: LEONATO’S BROTHER
sp.l: Content yourself. God knows I loved my niece,
And she is dead, slandered to death by villains
That dare as well answer a man indeed
As I dare take a serpent by the tongue.—
Boys, apes, braggarts, jacks, milksops!

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.l: Brother Anthony—

sp.speaker: LEONATO’S BROTHER
sp.l: Hold you content. What, man! I know them, yea,
And what they weigh, even to the utmost scruple—
Scambling, outfacing, fashionmonging boys,
That lie and cog and flout, deprave and slander,
Go anticly and show outward hideousness,
And speak off half a dozen dang’rous words
How they might hurt their enemies, if they durst,
And this is all.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.l: But brother Anthony—

sp.speaker: LEONATO’S BROTHER
sp.l: Come, ’tis no matter.
Do not you meddle. Let me deal in this.

sp.speaker: PRINCE
sp.l: Gentlemen both, we will not wake your patience.
My heart is sorry for your daughter’s death,
But, on my honor, she was charged with nothing
But what was true and very full of proof.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.l: My lord, my lord—

sp.speaker: PRINCE
sp.l: I will not hear you.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.l: No? Come, brother, away. I will be heard.

sp.speaker: LEONATO’S BROTHER
sp.l: And shall, or some of us will smart for it.

sp.speaker: PRINCE
sp.l: See, see, here comes the man we went to seek.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p: Now, signior, what news?

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p: Good day, my lord.

sp.speaker: PRINCE
sp.p:
Welcome, signior. You are almost come to
part almost a fray.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p:
We had like to have had our two noses
snapped off with two old men without teeth.

sp.speaker: PRINCE
sp.p:
Leonato and his brother. What think’st thou?
Had we fought, I doubt we should have been too
young for them.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
In a false quarrel there is no true valor. I
came to seek you both.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p:
We have been up and down to seek thee, for
we are high-proof melancholy and would fain have
it beaten away. Wilt thou use thy wit?

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p: It is in my scabbard. Shall I draw it?

sp.speaker: PRINCE
sp.p: Dost thou wear thy wit by thy side?

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p:
Never any did so, though very many have
been beside their wit. I will bid thee draw, as we do
the minstrels: draw to pleasure us.

sp.speaker: PRINCE
sp.p:
As I am an honest man, he looks pale.— Art
thou sick, or angry?

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p:
What, courage, man! What
though care killed a cat? Thou hast mettle enough
in thee to kill care.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
Sir, I shall meet your wit in the career, an
you charge it against me. I pray you, choose another
subject.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p:
Nay, then, give him another staff.
This last was broke ’cross.

sp.speaker: PRINCE
sp.p:
By this light, he changes more and more. I
think he be angry indeed.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p: If he be, he knows how to turn his girdle.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p: Shall I speak a word in your ear?

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p: God bless me from a challenge!

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
You are a villain. I jest
not. I will make it good how you dare, with what you
dare, and when you dare. Do me right, or I will
protest your cowardice. You have killed a sweet
lady, and her death shall fall heavy on you. Let me
hear from you.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p:
Well, I will meet you, so I may have good
cheer.

sp.speaker: PRINCE
sp.p: What, a feast, a feast?

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p:
I’ faith, I thank him. He hath bid me to a
calf’s head and a capon, the which if I do not carve
most curiously, say my knife’s naught. Shall I not
find a woodcock too?

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p: Sir, your wit ambles well; it goes easily.

sp.speaker: PRINCE
sp.p:
I’ll tell thee how Beatrice praised thy wit the
other day. I said thou hadst a fine wit. “ True,” said
she, “ a fine little one.” “ No,” said I, “ a great wit.”
“ Right,” says she, “ a great gross one.” “ Nay,” said I,
“ a good wit.” “ Just,” said she, “ it hurts nobody.”
“ Nay,” said I, “ the gentleman is wise.” “ Certain,”
said she, “ a wise gentleman.” “ Nay,” said I, “ he
hath the tongues.” “ That I believe,” said she, “ for he
swore a thing to me on Monday night which he
forswore on Tuesday morning; there’s a double
tongue, there’s two tongues.” Thus did she an hour
together transshape thy particular virtues. Yet at
last she concluded with a sigh, thou wast the
proper’st man in Italy.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p:
For the which she wept heartily and said she
cared not.

sp.speaker: PRINCE
sp.p:
Yea, that she did. But yet for all that, an if she
did not hate him deadly, she would love him
dearly. The old man’s daughter told us all.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p:
All, all. And, moreover, God saw him when
he was hid in the garden.

sp.speaker: PRINCE
sp.p:
But when shall we set the savage bull’s horns
on the sensible Benedick’s head?

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p:
Yea, and text underneath: “ Here dwells Benedick,
the married man”?

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
Fare you well, boy. You know my mind. I
will leave you now to your gossip-like humor. You
break jests as braggarts do their blades, which, God
be thanked, hurt not.— My lord, for your many
courtesies I thank you. I must discontinue your
company. Your brother the Bastard is fled from
Messina. You have among you killed a sweet and
innocent lady. For my Lord Lackbeard there, he and
I shall meet, and till then peace be with him.

sp.speaker: PRINCE
sp.p: He is in earnest.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p:
In most profound earnest, and, I’ll warrant
you, for the love of Beatrice.

sp.speaker: PRINCE
sp.p: And hath challenged thee?

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p: Most sincerely.

sp.speaker: PRINCE
sp.p:
What a pretty thing man is when he goes in his
doublet and hose and leaves off his wit!

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p:
He is then a giant to an ape; but then is an ape
a doctor to such a man.

sp.speaker: PRINCE
sp.p:
But soft you, let me be. Pluck up, my heart,
and be sad. Did he not say my brother was fled?

div.stage: Enter Constables Dogberry and Verges, and the Watch, with Conrade and Borachio.

sp.speaker: DOGBERRY
sp.p:
Come you, sir. If justice cannot tame you,
she shall ne’er weigh more reasons in her balance.
Nay, an you be a cursing hypocrite once, you must
be looked to.

sp.speaker: PRINCE
sp.p:
How now, two of my brother’s men bound?
Borachio one!

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p: Hearken after their offense, my lord.

sp.speaker: PRINCE
sp.p: Officers, what offense have these men done?

sp.speaker: DOGBERRY
sp.p:
Marry, sir, they have committed false
report; moreover, they have spoken untruths;
secondarily, they are slanders; sixth and lastly, they
have belied a lady; thirdly, they have verified unjust
things; and, to conclude, they are lying knaves.

sp.speaker: PRINCE
sp.p:
First, I ask thee what they have done; thirdly, I
ask thee what’s their offense; sixth and lastly, why
they are committed; and, to conclude, what you lay
to their charge.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p:
Rightly reasoned, and in his own division;
and, by my troth, there’s one meaning well suited.

sp.speaker: PRINCE
sp.p:
Who have you offended,
masters, that you are thus bound to your
answer? This learned constable is too cunning to be
understood. What’s your offense?

sp.speaker: BORACHIO
sp.p:
Sweet prince, let me go no farther to mine
answer. Do you hear me, and let this count kill me.
I have deceived even your very eyes. What your
wisdoms could not discover, these shallow fools
have brought to light, who in the night overheard
me confessing to this man how Don John your
brother incensed me to slander the Lady Hero, how
you were brought into the orchard and saw me
court Margaret in Hero’s garments, how you disgraced
her when you should marry her. My villainy
they have upon record, which I had rather seal with
my death than repeat over to my shame. The lady is
dead upon mine and my master’s false accusation.
And, briefly, I desire nothing but the reward of a
villain.

sp.speaker: PRINCE
sp.l: Runs not this speech like iron through your blood?

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.l: I have drunk poison whiles he uttered it.

sp.speaker: PRINCE
sp.l: But did my brother set thee on to this?

sp.speaker: BORACHIO
sp.p:
Yea, and paid me richly for the practice of
it.

sp.speaker: PRINCE
sp.l: He is composed and framed of treachery,
And fled he is upon this villainy.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.l: Sweet Hero, now thy image doth appear
In the rare semblance that I loved it first.

sp.speaker: DOGBERRY
sp.p:
Come, bring away the plaintiffs. By this
time our sexton hath reformed Signior Leonato of
the matter. And, masters, do not forget to specify,
when time and place shall serve, that I am an ass.

sp.speaker: VERGES
sp.p:
Here, here comes Master Signior Leonato,
and the Sexton too.

div.stage: Enter Leonato, his brother, and the Sexton.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.l: Which is the villain? Let me see his eyes,
That, when I note another man like him,
I may avoid him. Which of these is he?

sp.speaker: BORACHIO
sp.l: If you would know your wronger, look on me.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.l: Art thou the slave that with thy breath hast killed
Mine innocent child?

sp.speaker: BORACHIO
sp.l: Yea, even I alone.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.l: No, not so, villain, thou beliest thyself.
Here stand a pair of honorable men—
A third is fled— that had a hand in it.—
I thank you, princes, for my daughter’s death.
Record it with your high and worthy deeds.
’Twas bravely done, if you bethink you of it.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.l: I know not how to pray your patience,
Yet I must speak. Choose your revenge yourself.
Impose me to what penance your invention
Can lay upon my sin. Yet sinned I not
But in mistaking.

sp.speaker: PRINCE
sp.l: By my soul, nor I,
And yet to satisfy this good old man
I would bend under any heavy weight
That he’ll enjoin me to.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.l: I cannot bid you bid my daughter live—
That were impossible— but, I pray you both,
Possess the people in Messina here
How innocent she died. And if your love
Can labor aught in sad invention,
Hang her an epitaph upon her tomb
And sing it to her bones. Sing it tonight.
Tomorrow morning come you to my house,
And since you could not be my son-in-law,
Be yet my nephew. My brother hath a daughter,
Almost the copy of my child that’s dead,
And she alone is heir to both of us.
Give her the right you should have giv’n her cousin,
And so dies my revenge.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.l: O, noble sir!
Your overkindness doth wring tears from me.
I do embrace your offer and dispose
For henceforth of poor Claudio.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.l: Tomorrow then I will expect your coming.
Tonight I take my leave. This naughty man
Shall face to face be brought to Margaret,
Who I believe was packed in all this wrong,
Hired to it by your brother.

sp.speaker: BORACHIO
sp.l: No, by my soul, she was not,
Nor knew not what she did when she spoke to me,
But always hath been just and virtuous
In anything that I do know by her.

sp.speaker: DOGBERRY
sp.p:
Moreover, sir, which indeed is
not under white and black, this plaintiff here, the
offender, did call me ass. I beseech you, let it be
remembered in his punishment. And also the watch
heard them talk of one Deformed. They say he
wears a key in his ear and a lock hanging by it and
borrows money in God’s name, the which he hath
used so long and never paid that now men grow
hardhearted and will lend nothing for God’s sake.
Pray you, examine him upon that point.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p: I thank thee for thy care and honest pains.

sp.speaker: DOGBERRY
sp.p:
Your Worship speaks like a most thankful
and reverent youth, and I praise God for you.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p: There’s for thy pains.

sp.speaker: DOGBERRY
sp.p: God save the foundation.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p:
Go, I discharge thee of thy prisoner, and I
thank thee.

sp.speaker: DOGBERRY
sp.p:
I leave an arrant knave with your Worship,
which I beseech your Worship to correct
yourself, for the example of others. God keep your
Worship! I wish your Worship well. God restore you
to health. I humbly give you leave to depart, and if a
merry meeting may be wished, God prohibit it.—
Come, neighbor.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.l: Until tomorrow morning, lords, farewell.

sp.speaker: LEONATO’S BROTHER
sp.l: Farewell, my lords. We look for you tomorrow.

sp.speaker: PRINCE
sp.l: We will not fail.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.l: Tonight I’ll mourn with Hero.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.l: Bring you these fellows on.— We’ll talk with Margaret,
How her acquaintance grew with this lewd fellow.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
Pray thee, sweet Mistress Margaret, deserve
well at my hands by helping me to the speech of
Beatrice.

sp.speaker: MARGARET
sp.p:
Will you then write me a sonnet in praise
of my beauty?

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
In so high a style, Margaret, that no man
living shall come over it, for in most comely truth
thou deservest it.

sp.speaker: MARGARET
sp.p:
To have no man come over me? Why, shall I
always keep below stairs?

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
Thy wit is as quick as the greyhound’s
mouth; it catches.

sp.speaker: MARGARET
sp.p:
And yours as blunt as the fencer’s foils,
which hit but hurt not.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
A most manly wit, Margaret; it will not hurt
a woman. And so, I pray thee, call Beatrice. I give
thee the bucklers.

sp.speaker: MARGARET
sp.p:
Give us the swords; we have bucklers of our
own.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
If you use them, Margaret, you must put in
the pikes with a vice, and they are dangerous
weapons for maids.

sp.speaker: MARGARET
sp.p:
Well, I will call Beatrice to you, who I
think hath legs.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p: And therefore will come.

lg.l: The god of love
That sits above,
And knows me, and knows me,
How pitiful I deserve—

sp.p:
I mean in singing. But in loving, Leander the good
swimmer, Troilus the first employer of panders, and
a whole book full of these quondam carpetmongers,
whose names yet run smoothly in the even
road of a blank verse, why, they were never so truly
turned over and over as my poor self in love. Marry,
I cannot show it in rhyme. I have tried. I can find out
no rhyme to “ lady” but “ baby”— an innocent
rhyme; for “ scorn,” “ horn”— a hard rhyme; for
“ school,” “ fool”— a babbling rhyme; very ominous
endings. No, I was not born under a rhyming
planet, nor I cannot woo in festival terms.

Sweet Beatrice, wouldst thou come when I called
thee?

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p: Yea, signior, and depart when you bid me.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p: O, stay but till then!

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
“ Then” is spoken. Fare you well now. And
yet, ere I go, let me go with that I came, which is,
with knowing what hath passed between you and
Claudio.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
Only foul words, and thereupon I will kiss
thee.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
Foul words is but foul wind, and foul wind is
but foul breath, and foul breath is noisome. Therefore
I will depart unkissed.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
Thou hast frighted the word out of his right
sense, so forcible is thy wit. But I must tell thee
plainly, Claudio undergoes my challenge, and either
I must shortly hear from him, or I will subscribe
him a coward. And I pray thee now tell me, for
which of my bad parts didst thou first fall in love
with me?

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
For them all together, which maintained so
politic a state of evil that they will not admit any
good part to intermingle with them. But for which
of my good parts did you first suffer love for me?

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
Suffer love! A good epithet. I do suffer love
indeed, for I love thee against my will.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
In spite of your heart, I think. Alas, poor
heart, if you spite it for my sake, I will spite it for
yours, for I will never love that which my friend
hates.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p: Thou and I are too wise to woo peaceably.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
It appears not in this confession. There’s not
one wise man among twenty that will praise
himself.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
An old, an old instance, Beatrice, that lived
in the time of good neighbors. If a man do not erect
in this age his own tomb ere he dies, he shall live no
longer in monument than the bell rings and the
widow weeps.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p: And how long is that, think you?

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
Question: why, an hour in clamor and a
quarter in rheum. Therefore is it most expedient for
the wise, if Don Worm, his conscience, find no
impediment to the contrary, to be the trumpet of
his own virtues, as I am to myself. So much for
praising myself, who, I myself will bear witness, is
praiseworthy. And now tell me, how doth your
cousin?

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p: Very ill.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p: And how do you?

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p: Very ill, too.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
Serve God, love me, and mend. There will I
leave you too, for here comes one in haste.

sp.speaker: URSULA
sp.p:
Madam, you must come to your uncle. Yonder’s
old coil at home. It is proved my Lady Hero
hath been falsely accused, the Prince and Claudio
mightily abused, and Don John is the author of all,
who is fled and gone. Will you come presently?

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p: Will you go hear this news, signior?

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
I will live in thy heart, die in thy lap, and be
buried in thy eyes— and, moreover, I will go with
thee to thy uncle’s.

div.head: Scene 3
div.stage: Enter Claudio, Prince, and three or four Lords with tapers, and Musicians.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p: Is this the monument of Leonato?

sp.speaker: FIRST LORD
sp.p: It is, my lord.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO

lg.l: Done to death by slanderous tongues
Was the Hero that here lies.
Death, in guerdon of her wrongs,
Gives her fame which never dies.
So the life that died with shame
Lives in death with glorious fame.

sp.l: Hang thou there upon the tomb,
Praising her when I am dumb.
Now music, sound, and sing your solemn hymn.

div.label: Song

lg.l: Pardon, goddess of the night,
Those that slew thy virgin knight,
For the which with songs of woe,
Round about her tomb they go.
Midnight, assist our moan.
Help us to sigh and groan
Heavily, heavily.
Graves, yawn and yield your dead,
Till death be utterèd,
Heavily, heavily.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.l: Now, unto thy bones, goodnight.
Yearly will I do this rite.

sp.speaker: PRINCE
sp.l: Good morrow, masters. Put your torches out.
The wolves have preyed, and look, the gentle day
Before the wheels of Phoebus, round about
Dapples the drowsy east with spots of gray.
Thanks to you all, and leave us. Fare you well.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.l: Good morrow, masters. Each his several way.

sp.speaker: PRINCE
sp.l: Come, let us hence, and put on other weeds,
And then to Leonato’s we will go.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.l: And Hymen now with luckier issue speed ’s,
Than this for whom we rendered up this woe.

div.head: Scene 4
div.stage: Enter Leonato, Benedick, Beatrice, Margaret, Ursula, Leonato’s brother, Friar, Hero.

sp.speaker: FRIAR
sp.l: Did I not tell you she was innocent?

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.l: So are the Prince and Claudio, who accused her
Upon the error that you heard debated.
But Margaret was in some fault for this,
Although against her will, as it appears
In the true course of all the question.

sp.speaker: LEONATO’S BROTHER
sp.l: Well, I am glad that all things sorts so well.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.l: And so am I, being else by faith enforced
To call young Claudio to a reckoning for it.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.l: Well, daughter, and you gentlewomen all,
Withdraw into a chamber by yourselves,
And when I send for you, come hither masked.
The Prince and Claudio promised by this hour
To visit me.— You know your office, brother.
You must be father to your brother’s daughter,
And give her to young Claudio.

sp.speaker: LEONATO’S BROTHER
sp.l: Which I will do with confirmed countenance.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.l: Friar, I must entreat your pains, I think.

sp.speaker: FRIAR
sp.l: To do what, signior?

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.l: To bind me, or undo me, one of them.—
Signior Leonato, truth it is, good signior,
Your niece regards me with an eye of favor.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.l: That eye my daughter lent her; ’tis most true.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.l: And I do with an eye of love requite her.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.l: The sight whereof I think you had from me,
From Claudio, and the Prince. But what’s your will?

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.l: Your answer, sir, is enigmatical.
But for my will, my will is your goodwill
May stand with ours, this day to be conjoined
In the state of honorable marriage—
In which, good friar, I shall desire your help.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.l: My heart is with your liking.

sp.speaker: FRIAR
sp.l: And my help.
Here comes the Prince and Claudio.

div.stage: Enter Prince, and Claudio, and two or three other.

sp.speaker: PRINCE
sp.l: Good morrow to this fair assembly.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.l: Good morrow, prince; good morrow, Claudio.
We here attend you. Are you yet determined
Today to marry with my brother’s daughter?

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.l: I’ll hold my mind were she an Ethiope.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.l: Call her forth, brother. Here’s the Friar ready.

sp.speaker: PRINCE
sp.l: Good morrow, Benedick. Why, what’s the matter
That you have such a February face,
So full of frost, of storm, and cloudiness?

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.l: I think he thinks upon the savage bull.
Tush, fear not, man. We’ll tip thy horns with gold,
And all Europa shall rejoice at thee,
As once Europa did at lusty Jove
When he would play the noble beast in love.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.l: Bull Jove, sir, had an amiable low,
And some such strange bull leapt your father’s cow
And got a calf in that same noble feat
Much like to you, for you have just his bleat.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.l: For this I owe you. Here comes other reck’nings.
sp.stage: Enter Leonato’s brother, Hero, Beatrice, Margaret, Ursula, the ladies masked.
sp.l: Which is the lady I must seize upon?

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.l: This same is she, and I do give you her.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.l: Why, then, she’s mine.— Sweet, let me see your face.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.l: No, that you shall not till you take her hand
Before this friar and swear to marry her.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.l: Give me your hand before this holy friar.
I am your husband, if you like of me.

sp.speaker: HERO
sp.l: And when I lived, I was your other wife,
And when you loved, you were my other husband.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.l: Another Hero!

sp.speaker: HERO
sp.l: Nothing certainer.
One Hero died defiled, but I do live,
And surely as I live, I am a maid.

sp.speaker: PRINCE
sp.l: The former Hero! Hero that is dead!

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.l: She died, my lord, but whiles her slander lived.

sp.speaker: FRIAR
sp.l: All this amazement can I qualify,
When after that the holy rites are ended,
I’ll tell you largely of fair Hero’s death.
Meantime let wonder seem familiar,
And to the chapel let us presently.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.l: Soft and fair, friar.— Which is Beatrice?

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.l: I answer to that name. What is your will?

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.l: Do not you love me?

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.l: Why no, no more than reason.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.l: Why then, your uncle and the Prince and Claudio
Have been deceived. They swore you did.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.l: Do not you love me?

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.l: Troth, no, no more than reason.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.l: Why then, my cousin, Margaret, and Ursula
Are much deceived, for they did swear you did.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.l: They swore that you were almost sick for me.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.l: They swore that you were well-nigh dead for me.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.l: ’Tis no such matter. Then you do not love me?

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.l: No, truly, but in friendly recompense.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.l: Come, cousin, I am sure you love the gentleman.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.l: And I’ll be sworn upon ’t that he loves her,
For here’s a paper written in his hand,
A halting sonnet of his own pure brain,
Fashioned to Beatrice.

sp.speaker: HERO
sp.l: And here’s another,
Writ in my cousin’s hand, stol’n from her pocket,
Containing her affection unto Benedick.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
A miracle! Here’s our own hands against
our hearts. Come, I will have thee, but by this light
I take thee for pity.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
I would not deny you, but by this good day, I
yield upon great persuasion, and partly to save your
life, for I was told you were in a consumption.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p: Peace! I will stop your mouth.

sp.speaker: PRINCE
sp.l: How dost thou, Benedick, the married man?

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
I’ll tell thee what, prince: a college of
wit-crackers cannot flout me out of my humor.
Dost thou think I care for a satire or an epigram?
No. If a man will be beaten with brains, he shall
wear nothing handsome about him. In brief, since I
do purpose to marry, I will think nothing to any
purpose that the world can say against it, and
therefore never flout at me for what I have said
against it. For man is a giddy thing, and this is my
conclusion.— For thy part, Claudio, I did think to
have beaten thee, but in that thou art like to be my
kinsman, live unbruised, and love my cousin.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p:
I had well hoped thou wouldst have denied
Beatrice, that I might have cudgeled thee out of thy
single life, to make thee a double-dealer, which out
of question thou wilt be, if my cousin do not look
exceeding narrowly to thee.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
Come, come, we are friends. Let’s have a
dance ere we are married, that we may lighten our
own hearts and our wives’ heels.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p: We’ll have dancing afterward.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
First, of my word! Therefore play, music.—
Prince, thou art sad. Get thee a wife, get thee a wife.
There is no staff more reverend than one tipped
with horn.

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: My lord, your brother John is ta’en in flight,
And brought with armed men back to Messina.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
Think not on him till tomorrow.
I’ll devise thee brave punishments for him.— Strike
up, pipers!
